content:
I love the Seabridge Gold (SA) trade we made yesterday.

The stock is cheap. The SA January 15 call options are cheap. We have tons of upside profit potential. And we have limited risk on the downside.

It's a terrific trade setup... But we can do even better.

Today, I'm going to show you how I would trade Seabridge with my own money. Stansberry & Associates' policy doesn't allow me to put money into the trades I write about. But if I could, I would do something a little more evolved than just simply buying call options.

Don't get me wrong. I love the SA January 15 call options. I expect the trade will work out well. But any time you buy options, you stand almost a 70% chance of losing money on the trade.

We have a much better success rate here in the S&A Short Report. But from a pure statistical measure, option buyers will lose money almost 70% of the time. Here's why...

Stocks can do one of three things. They can go up... They can go down... Or they can stay the same.

When you buy a call option, you're betting the stock will go up. So you'll lose money if the stock goes down or stays the same. You also lose money if the stock goes up... but not enough to recoup the cost of your option premium.

That's why most people lose money when they buy options. They'll be wrong every two out of three trades on average. Even when they're right, they lose because the stock didn't move enough in the direction they wanted it to.

It's tough to beat those kinds of odds... But you can do it if you're willing to be a little more creative.

Most folks won't do what I'm about to show you. I know this because I've recommended this strategy a few times previously in the S&A Short Report. Each time I did, our customer service department was flooded with complaints.

"Don't give me some complex option trade," a subscriber would say. "Just tell me which option I should buy and then when I should sell it."

In other words, many of you want me to keep it simple. I get it. I will continue to dedicate my time each week to finding you the best low-risk/high-reward option trades available. That has been my promise from the beginning, and it won't ever change.

But if you'd like to increase your odds of success... if you'd like to see the real potential in the options market... if you'd like to learn how I was able to retire when I was 42 years old... you need to learn this strategy.

How You Can Make Money... Even If You're Wrong

Before I ever buy an option, the question I always ask myself is, "How can I make money on this trade, even if I'm wrong?"

The answer sets the stage for this strategy. Let's take yesterday's Seabridge Gold trade for example...

We bought the SA January 15 call options for about $1.65, and we're off to a good start. Shares rallied higher yesterday, and the options we bought closed at $1.85. But no matter how much I love this trade – and even though we're already sitting on a profit – the only way we'll guarantee a gain is if SA closes above $16.65 on option expiration day in January.

If SA falls in price, we'll lose money. If SA stays the same, we'll lose money. If SA doesn't rally more than 25% by January, we'll lose money.

Frankly, I think the stock will be much higher a few months from now. But let's face it... there are lots of ways to lose money on this trade. So let's figure out a way to increase our chances of being right.

We spent up to $1.65 to buy the SA January 15 call options. As long as we're spending money out of our pocket to make this option trade, the odds are against us. But there's a way to put some money back into our pocket... without taking on any extra risk.

The easiest way to do this is to create a spread trade.

Spreads involve buying one series of options and then selling another.

Since we own the SA January 15 call options, we have the right to buy the stock at $15. To create a spread, we'll sell someone else the right to buy SA from us at a higher price.

My initial upside target for SA is around $20 per share. We'll sell the right to buy the stock from us at $20. The SA January 20 call options closed yesterday at $0.85. We can recoup more than 50% of the cost of the January 15 calls by selling the January 20 calls against it.

Here's how that looks if we're trading one contract at a time. (Remember: a contract covers 100 shares.)

Action
Option
Ticker
Definition
Total
Buy
SA January 15 calls
SA130119C00015000
Right to buy
SA at $15
Spend $165
Sell, to open
SA January 20 calls
SA130119C00020000
Obligation to sell
SA at $20
Collect $85
Total net cost: $80
Please note: each contract covers 100 shares

We're paying $165 for the right to buy SA at $15 per share and receiving $85 for taking on the obligation to sell SA at $20 per share. We're spending $80 for each spread. That's just $0.80 per share.

We've immediately lowered our out-of-pocket cost for this trade from $165 to just $80. Our maximum loss is now less than half what it was before.

That also means our maximum profit is reduced. Since we've sold someone else the right to buy SA from us at $20, we won't make any additional profit if SA rallies above that level. But because $20 per share was our initial target anyway, odds are we'd be looking to lock in profits on the trade at that price. So we're really just agreeing to do so ahead of time.

Now, think about this...

If SA closes at $20 per share on option expiration day in January, the SA January 15 call options are worth $500 per contract. We spent $165 on the original trade. So we have a $335 profit, or 203% gains on our initial $165 investment.

But by creating the spread, we've reduced the cost of the trade to just $80. And with SA at $20 per share on option expiration day, the spread will still be worth $500. Now we have a $420 gain. That's 525% on the original investment.

The spread position lowered our cost of the trade, so it also lowered our risk and increased our potential profit.

This is a BIG improvement over just buying the January 15 call options outright. But we can still do even better.

Even with this spread trade, we're still only going to profit if the stock moves higher. We'll lose money if SA falls or stays the same. To increase our chances for a profit, we need to add one more leg to this option position...

How Selling Puts Works

Selling uncovered puts is my favorite option strategy. In my experience, it is the most consistent way to profit in the options market. By selling uncovered puts, you're getting paid to agree to buy a stock at a specified price by some date in the future. It is that simple.

For example, let's say you'd be willing to pay $22 per share to own Intel (INTC) if it drops to that level by October. INTC closed yesterday at $26. So you're willing to buy it if it drops 15% from here.

The INTC October 22 put options are trading for $0.65. You can sell one contract and collect $65 just for agreeing to buy Intel if it drops to $22 by option expiration day in October. If INTC never falls to $22, the option will expire worthless. You'll keep the $65 and be under no further obligation. If INTC drops below $22 per share, you'll pay $22 for the stock – which is what you wanted to do anyway... And you still get to keep the $65 option premium for selling the put.

It is important to only sell uncovered put options on stocks you want to own anyway... and at prices at which you'd like to own them.

In a rapidly falling stock market – which occurs just about once per year – you may end up having to buy the stocks on which you've sold puts. If you don't like Intel and wouldn't want to own it at any price, don't sell uncovered puts on it.

Most folks who use this strategy use it to generate income on stocks they don't currently own but would like to for the right price. We're going to use it to pay for our call options trades. Here's how...

Get Paid to Trade

The Seabridge Gold spread trade described above costs $80 for each position. We need to sell an uncovered put option on SA that will get the $80 back and maybe even put a little extra money in our pocket up front.

Remember... we only sell puts on stocks we want to own anyway and at prices at which we want to own them. SA is a dirt-cheap gold stock that I wouldn't mind buying at the current price. I'd be thrilled to get paid for agreeing to buy it even cheaper.

The SA January 10 put options closed yesterday at $1.10. That's $110 per option contract. By selling this put, we'd collect $110 – which covers the cost of our spread trade and puts another $30 more in our pocket – and we'd be obligated to buy SA at $10 per share if it closes below that level on option expiration day in January.

Here's how the entire SA option combination trade now looks...

Action
Option
Ticker
Definition
Total
Buy
SA January 15 calls
SA130119C00015000
Right to buy
SA at $15
Spend $165
Sell, to open
SA January 20 calls
SA130119C0002000
Obligation to sell
SA at $20
Collect $85
Sell, to open
SA January 10 puts
SA130119P00010000
Obligation to buy
SA at $10
Collect $110
Total net cost: $30
Please note: each contract covers 100 shares

We now have a trade that pays us $30 to set it up. That $30 is ours to keep no matter what happens to SA.

This trade can play out in one of four ways...

1. SA closes below $10 on January expiration day. We're obligated to buy 100 shares of SA at $10 per share. If we figure in the $30 we received for setting up the trade, we're really agreeing to buy the stock at $9.70. So this trade will be profitable as long as SA holds above $9.70 per share.

In other words, the only way we can lose money on this option combination is if SA drops another 25% from its already-depressed stock price. We make money in every other scenario.

2. SA closes between $10 and $15 per share on January expiration day. All the options in the combination expire worthless, and we keep the $30 per contract.

3. SA closes between $15 and $20 per share. The higher SA trades in that range, the more money we make.

4. SA closes above $20 per share. The spread is worth $500. So our maximum profit is $530 ($500 from the spread and $30 for the original setup of the trade).

Now... think about what we've done here...

We took the original call option position – which cost $165 and would create a $335 profit if SA rallied to $20 per share – and turned it into a trade that put $30 in our pocket right away and could return another $500 if the stock rallies.

Instead of having a position that would lose money if SA went down, stayed the same, or failed to move up 25% over the next eight months... we now have a trade that is profitable under every scenario as long as the stock doesn't fall by more than 25%.

As much as I like the SA call purchase I recommended yesterday, I love this combination trade even more.

How to Make This Trade

If you are interested in executing this trade, there are a couple things you have to do with your broker first. For starters, you need to get approval for spread trading and for selling uncovered put options. In most cases, you'll just need to update your option account form and submit it to your broker for approval. Some brokerages require a minimum amount of option trading experience (usually three years or more) and a minimum account size (around $25,000).

Also, since selling uncovered put options obligates you to possibly buy the underlying stock, most firms require a margin deposit of about 20% of the purchase obligation before making the trade. In this SA example, selling one SA January 10 put option obligates you to buy 100 shares of SA at $10 per share. That's a total purchase obligation of $1,000. So your broker may require a $200 margin deposit.

Finally... I know there are a lot of steps to this type of trading, and it may seem a bit complex at first. But the financial payoff is well-worth the effort to learn this strategy. By using combination trades, you'll reduce your risk, increase your returns, and dramatically improve your chances of profiting on any option trade.

I won't be tracking this trade as a formal S&A Short Report recommendation, though I may comment on it from time to time in the updates. This is just designed to show you another way – a better way – of making money in the options market. Consider it a bonus to your S&A Short Report subscription.

Best regards and good trading,

Jeff Clark

Please send your S&A Short Report feedback here. Although I can't respond individually, I read every e-mail. Because many subscribers had similar questions about options trading, we put together the "S&A Guide to Options Trading." You can also read through our Frequently Asked Questions section.

For real-time market commentary and trading ideas 
from Jeff Clark, check out the Direct Line, a 
bonus service for S&A Short Report subscribers.

title: How I Trade with My Own Money
